title: Why we are mad about Mars
text:
My favourite Martian: behind the science is the story of why we love Mars Rod Chester News Corp Australia Network My favourite Martian: behind the science is the story of why we love Mars Rod Chester News Corp Australia Network Help wanted ... the Disney animated film Mars Needs Moms is just one in a long line of failed Mars movies 
THE story declared in the headlines of the last week is simple. If there is water, there is a possibility of life, with the story either having the twist of “once upon a time” of back in the day or a “build it and they will come” idea that water now means the red planet could sustain a manned base in the future. 
NASA’s announcement last week of evidence of water on Mars could not have come at a better time for many. For the space agency, it helps focus the world’s attention on the current and future robotic missions to Mars and the eventual plans for manned missions to make that next giant leap. Also, Matt Damon and his mates from the movie The Martian must be wondering how they managed it strike it so lucky. 
Martians, in cultural terms, are very special non-people. 
Daniel Price, a senior lecturer and Australian Research Council Future Fellow in astrophysics at Monash University, says one of the reasons people obsess about Martians and not Saturnians or other planetary species is partly one of familiarity. 
“It’s not so different to the early Earth in terms of what might have happened there,” he says 
“And that’s the real fascination. Did life get started on Mars? Other Stories
